trans-unit.source: Service Bus queues support a brokered messaging communication model.
trans-unit.target: Service Bus queues support a brokered messaging communication model.

trans-unit.source: When using queues, components of a distributed application do not communicate directly with each other; instead they exchange messages via a queue, which acts as an intermediary (broker).
trans-unit.target: When using queues, components of a distributed application do not communicate directly with each other; instead they exchange messages via a queue, which acts as an intermediary (broker).

trans-unit.source: A message producer (sender) hands off a message to the queue and then continues its processing.
trans-unit.target: A message producer (sender) hands off a message to the queue and then continues its processing.

trans-unit.source: Asynchronously, a message consumer (receiver) pulls the message from the queue and processes it.
trans-unit.target: Asynchronously, a message consumer (receiver) pulls the message from the queue and processes it.

trans-unit.source: The producer does not have to wait for a reply from the consumer in order to continue to process and send further messages.
trans-unit.target: The producer does not have to wait for a reply from the consumer in order to continue to process and send further messages.

trans-unit.source: Queues offer First In, First Out (FIFO) message delivery to one or more competing consumers.
trans-unit.target: Queues offer First In, First Out (FIFO) message delivery to one or more competing consumers.

trans-unit.source: That is, messages are typically received and processed by the receivers in the order in which they were added to the queue, and each message is received and processed by only one message consumer.
trans-unit.target: That is, messages are typically received and processed by the receivers in the order in which they were added to the queue, and each message is received and processed by only one message consumer.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>QueueConcepts</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>QueueConcepts</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Service Bus queues are a general-purpose technology that can be used for a wide variety of scenarios:
trans-unit.target: Service Bus queues are a general-purpose technology that can be used for a wide variety of scenarios:

trans-unit.source: Communication between web and worker roles in a multi-tier Azure application.
trans-unit.target: Communication between web and worker roles in a multi-tier Azure application.

trans-unit.source: Communication between on-premises apps and Azure hosted apps in a hybrid solution.
trans-unit.target: Communication between on-premises apps and Azure hosted apps in a hybrid solution.

trans-unit.source: Communication between components of a distributed application running on-premises in different organizations or departments of an organization.
trans-unit.target: Communication between components of a distributed application running on-premises in different organizations or departments of an organization.

trans-unit.source: Using queues enables you to scale out your applications more easily, and enable more resiliency to your architecture.
trans-unit.target: Using queues enables you to scale out your applications more easily, and enable more resiliency to your architecture.

trans-unit.source: To begin using Service Bus queues in Azure, you must first create a service namespace.
trans-unit.target: To begin using Service Bus queues in Azure, you must first create a service namespace.

trans-unit.source: A namespace provides a scoping container for addressing Service Bus resources within your application.
trans-unit.target: A namespace provides a scoping container for addressing Service Bus resources within your application.

trans-unit.source: To create a service namespace:
trans-unit.target: To create a service namespace:

trans-unit.source: Log on to the <linkText>Azure Management Portal</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Log on to the <linkText>Azure Management Portal</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: In the left navigation pane of the Management Portal, click Service Bus.
trans-unit.target: In the left navigation pane of the Management Portal, click Service Bus.

trans-unit.source: In the lower pane of the Management Portal, click Create.
trans-unit.target: In the lower pane of the Management Portal, click Create.

trans-unit.source: In the Add a new namespace dialog, enter a namespace name.
trans-unit.target: In the Add a new namespace dialog, enter a namespace name.

trans-unit.source: The system immediately checks to see if the name is available.
trans-unit.target: The system immediately checks to see if the name is available.

trans-unit.source: After making sure the namespace name is available, choose the country or region in which your namespace should be hosted (make sure you use the same country/region in which you are deploying your compute resources).
trans-unit.target: After making sure the namespace name is available, choose the country or region in which your namespace should be hosted (make sure you use the same country/region in which you are deploying your compute resources).

trans-unit.source: IMPORTANT: Pick the same region that you intend to choose for deploying your application.
trans-unit.target: IMPORTANT: Pick the same region that you intend to choose for deploying your application.

trans-unit.source: This will give you the best performance.
trans-unit.target: This will give you the best performance.

trans-unit.source: Leave the other fields in the dialog with their default values (Messaging and Standard Tier), then click the check mark.
trans-unit.target: Leave the other fields in the dialog with their default values (Messaging and Standard Tier), then click the check mark.

trans-unit.source: The system now creates your namespace and enables it.
trans-unit.target: The system now creates your namespace and enables it.

trans-unit.source: You might have to wait several minutes as the system provisions resources for your account.
trans-unit.target: You might have to wait several minutes as the system provisions resources for your account.

trans-unit.source: The namespace you created takes a moment to activate, and will then appear in the management portal.
trans-unit.target: The namespace you created takes a moment to activate, and will then appear in the management portal.

trans-unit.source: Wait until the namespace status is Active before continuing.
trans-unit.target: Wait until the namespace status is Active before continuing.

trans-unit.source: In order to perform management operations, such as creating a queue on the new namespace, you must obtain the management credentials for the namespace.
trans-unit.target: In order to perform management operations, such as creating a queue on the new namespace, you must obtain the management credentials for the namespace.

trans-unit.source: You can obtain these credentials from either the Azure management portal, or from the Visual Studio Server Explorer.
trans-unit.target: You can obtain these credentials from either the Azure management portal, or from the Visual Studio Server Explorer.

trans-unit.source: In the left navigation pane, click the Service Bus node, to display the list of available namespaces:
trans-unit.target: In the left navigation pane, click the Service Bus node, to display the list of available namespaces:

trans-unit.source: Select the namespace you just created from the list shown: <linkText></linkText>
trans-unit.target: Select the namespace you just created from the list shown: <linkText></linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click Connection Information.
trans-unit.target: Click Connection Information.

trans-unit.source: In the Access connection information pane, find the connection string that contains the SAS key and key name.
trans-unit.target: In the Access connection information pane, find the connection string that contains the SAS key and key name.

trans-unit.source: Make a note of the key, or copy it to the clipboard.
trans-unit.target: Make a note of the key, or copy it to the clipboard.

trans-unit.source: To obtain connection information using Visual Studio instead of the management portal, follow the procedure described here, in the section titled To connect to Azure from Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: To obtain connection information using Visual Studio instead of the management portal, follow the procedure described here, in the section titled To connect to Azure from Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: When you sign in to Azure, the Service Bus node under the Azure tree in Server Explorer is automatically populated with any namespaces you've already created.
trans-unit.target: When you sign in to Azure, the Service Bus node under the Azure tree in Server Explorer is automatically populated with any namespaces you've already created.

trans-unit.source: Right-click any namespace, and then click Properties to see the connection string and other metadata associated with this namespace displayed in the Visual Studio Properties pane.
trans-unit.target: Right-click any namespace, and then click Properties to see the connection string and other metadata associated with this namespace displayed in the Visual Studio Properties pane.

trans-unit.source: Make a note of the SharedAccessKey value, or copy it to the clipboard:
trans-unit.target: Make a note of the SharedAccessKey value, or copy it to the clipboard:

trans-unit.source: http://manage.windowsazure.com
trans-unit.target: http://manage.windowsazure.com

trans-unit.source: http://manage.windowsazure.com
trans-unit.target: http://manage.windowsazure.com
